content: So I have a question especially targeted to team members and contributors: a lot people in the contributor survey expressed feeling bad about "wasting busy expert time" by asking questions. So my question is do you feel like questions from less experience contributors are disruptive to you or slowing you down?
I ask because if it doesn't, then the solution is simply to encourage people to ask questions, but if it does, we need another solution...
my only problem is when people PM me
when it would be better to ask questions in a public channel
I can understand why someone might PM, since it seems good to only distract one person rather than worry about causing your Question to end up in the notification list for every member of the team
ah, i wonder if others feel that way... I tend to PM others quite often
and in practice I usually just try to respond with "hey good question, but lets move it to a private area"
@pnkfelix is your reasoning that if they asked in a public channel, others could see the answer too?
well, maybe I'm not always that nice about it. I think my issue is that I interpret PM's as being for high priority items
good to know
Yes, I think public channels are better for general knowledge distribution
since both other readers can learn, and also other people can clarify the answer
But I have to admit that my own personal interpretation of PM's as being for high priority items is probably something that ends up being a bigger issue in my head
FWIW Zulip's UI makes PMs horrible because you get a notification for every single message
and there's no way to mute that
whereas I can follow along in a public stream and respond from time to time and get pinged periodically and that's fine
you can mute the notifications for PMs entirely, no?
(not that I've tried: I'm just skimming the settings after seeing @simulacrum 's message...)
While I do generally prefer getting pinged on public channels, I have no problems with PMs. Also yea, I don't feel like anyone's wasting my time by asking me stuff. ppl should definitely ask
hm yeah but I would like one notification, as you say, PMs can be "urgent" in some sense
I agree that I'm happy to answer questions in public channels
Maybe if we write a paragraph on asking questions in the Rustc Dev Guide, people would feel more comfortable asking?
Is there anyone who thinks PM's are better?
(not merely "fine", but actually preferable, either for them personally, or for the good of the group as a whole, as I hypothesized above in a devil's advocate manner?)

I think PMs actually have a lower entry barrier for ppl to contact me, because their message is not exposed to the world. (And I hope that everyone knows nothing they write me is annoying to me or will make me laugh at them). I have sometimes said "let's take this to a public channel", but only if I think it impacts/helps others for the discussion to be public.
hmm. So I guess there needs to be a decision collectively about how people in general feel about this

I'm not a compiler expert, but I guess that since Zulip allows for parallel discussions, you can open a new discussion without it interfering with other running discussions. However, newcomers might not consider this and prefer PMs to not disturb running conversations.
if most people do not interpret PM's as "high priority interruptions" or are not otherwise annoyed by getting them, then maybe our policy shouldn't discourage PM's.
at the very least it seems worth double checking about this at a team meeting, either today or on Thursday
(at least, I don't want to be the sole reason that we end up adding language discouraging PM's, even though I personally would prefer that.)
Note that you can actually ping someone in a PM and it'll show up in @mentions
you mean in ... a PM you're not otherwise participating in?
so maybe it's possible to disable PM notifications and just keep @mention notifications?
no
okay phew
in my own PMs ppl have pinged me xD
don't worry, PMs mentioning other ppl doesn't ping them, I've experimented on this
that'd be awkward

I try to avoid PMs where I can - with the exception of when using Discord - because I don't mind asking a question publicly and it can be helpful for other people to see what's going on and jump in. I definitely understand why some people might not feel comfortable asking questions publicly - but I'm not sure we should encourage PMs because of that, though I think it'd make sense to not-discourage them.
Hm I should explore the notification thing, @oli - if that's true, then I don't mind PMs either. Though I would still prefer to help in public to hopefully ease later someone uplifting to dev guide

Definitely, but anything we can do to reduce the barrier for first contact is a good thing in my book. I've frequently moved from PM to public discussion, and maybe I should do that more aggressively.
I've literally had ppl write me "idk where to ask this, so I'm contacting you"
Sure! I wonder if having e.g. history and logging for /help disabled like we did on irc for beginners would be of interest

oli said:

I've literally had ppl write me "idk where to ask this, so I'm contacting you"

This I can understand and try not to get annoyed by
(I think we can't disable history entirely, but maybe just the "if you join you don't see things before you did")
"you don't see things before you did" ?
oh before you joined?
yeah
by "history" I thought @simulacrum meant the zulip-archive
Actually, you can't do protected history in a public stream.
That's one of the two options for private streams - protected and non-protected history.
Ah okay
Well, we can at least get rid of archiving
It's probably something that upstream would be willing to add.
I'm confused in part because I wasn't even aware that /help existed here. And playing in #zulip > test123 indicates that it doesn't, at least not there?
I assumed @simulacrum meant #t-compiler/help, the stream.
oh
Maybe we can do something to make it more obvious that e.g. t-compiler/help stream is the place to ask questions, and that includes beginners
this is a very interesting discussion and good to know how it bothers some people as someone that is not bothered by PMs and use to send PMs
Zulip notification system has a lot to improve, that's clear, I kind of tend to shutdown all the notifications when I want to be focused on something
@eddyb had some good complaints about Zulip notification system, maybe we should ask them to improve? :)

btw, one thing that I personally like about PMs is the closer kind of interactions it allows you to generate, I got to know a lot about contributors without personally having spent a lot of time with them
unsure how much people value this though :)
so as an update: it looks like PMs and mentions are connected in the UI
image.png

Santiago Pastorino said:

btw, one thing that I personally like about PMs is the closer kind of interactions it allows you to generate, I got to know a lot about contributors without personally having spent a lot of time with them

That's one thing that I feel like I've missed out on - I don't think I know many of the other contributors very well, and partly that's because I've only really used public channels. I noticed the difference when chatting with eddyb during the bulk of the polymorphisation work, we got to chatting more and that was nice.
(in general, I think that is something that it feels like Discord encourages more)
It's an interesting problem for sure
Discord encourages more PMs because it's hard to keep focused discussions, imagine discussing things in #compiler 40 topics interleaved in the same space :)
Even in #compiler in Discord though, it feels more chatty a lot of the time than any Zulip topic does.
yeah, I have no idea about that because I don't follow it, it's impossible for me to follow something like #compiler in Discord
This ... is a super interesting point. I have to admit, I hadn't considered that we might be losing some elements of, well, "social community" with the move to Zulip
well I'm not sure if I'd agree with that aspect
all I'm trying to say is ... the social aspect works better with PMs
regardless of Discord/Zulip
but then its only pair-wise social?
and not, I dunno, a nice cocktail party kind of socialness?
but you can socialize in groups here as you do in Discord
That could just be because there's never been a #compiler-people-hangout room in either platform
what I guess is that given that Discord kind of forces you to send PMs because it's hard to have 40 topics being discussed in one place, you end interacting more in one to one with people
indeed. It seems like a #socializing stream could be reasonable.
but what I'm saying is that you could totally do that here too
well also a stream could work too
but my feeling is that in that regard PMs are always better
why is that, do you suppose? Just because people feel more at ease to share stuff over PM?
but it's good to know that this bothers some people
e.g. an ability to speak frankly, for example?
I'm honestly curious
well I'd be willing to disclose personal aspects of my life with you in private than in a public channel
not opposed to share those with compiler members
no its true
FWIW we could (easily) have a private stream to that effect
especially since all these communications end up on zulip-archive.rlo
yep
I think, in the wake of coronavirus stuff, a #socializing stream makes a lot of sense
and it can be private, sure
(I don't actually know what private stream means, in terms of how the messages/content gets restricted.)
(e.g. are private streams invite-only to join/view ?)
image.png
(those are Zulip's stream settings regarding who can see/post)
We need a fourth option: "forgetful" where the channel just drops all messages after a day or so
(but the channel is still public)
in theory you could do that with the API I imagine, but maybe nice to have it builtin
It might be nice to have a "scheduled" hangout. Not mandatory but just schedule a time where other people will be online with the intent of having not-rust conversation :slight_smile:

pnkfelix said:

my only problem is when people PM me

by the way, this was ambiguous. I meant here to say that my problem is when people I do not know PM me
Maybe do some poll questions with those stupid "ice breakers" like "If you could have any super power, what would it be?" IDK, might be kind of fun.
(if I already know you, or if we've had some form of chat somewhere, feel free to PM me...)
((maybe all of this is leftover stress from when I was a member of rust-mods))
this discussion have been seriously very interesting
I second a private socializing stream :)

@mark-i-m

So I have a question especially targeted to team members and contributors: a lot people in the contributor survey expressed feeling bad about "wasting busy expert time" by asking questions. So my question is do you feel like questions from less experience contributors are disruptive to you or slowing you down?

I feel like Rust does particularly well in this area, in a specific way. It seems like many team members treat questions and mentoring as a high priority, specifically because that way we end up with more experts in the future, which reduces the bottleneck.
In other words, people seem to treat "only one person can do this" as a bug, and relish opportunities to increase that number.

I don't mind being asked but I feel like there's probably a bit more going on than just telling people "don't feel bad". I thought @Wesley Wiser made good points that having an explicit structure of "here's the person to ask" is helpful, and it also addresses the problem of "I don't know who's the right person to ask".
I guess I will say that while I don't mind getting questions, I do get fairly regular "drive-by pings" that I only rarely have the energy to read and respond to

pnkfelix said:

This ... is a super interesting point. I have to admit, I hadn't considered that we might be losing some elements of, well, "social community" with the move to Zulip

fwiw I had considered this and considered it a plus, but maybe it's not as much a clear plus as I thought... I do kind of think that "chattiness" can be also kind of frustrating and distracting at times, when you're trying to "get work done" :)
I agree with that, and think that's why I would only want a separate steam here, if anything

Random thought: We have a CoC which formalizes what bad behavior is, but I'm not aware of any kind of document that gives "etiquette" advice and formalizes what behaviors we want to encourage. Such a document would be a good place to point out that PM'ing questions to various people is allowed/encouraged but drive by pings aren't really helpful.
Yes.
BTW, one interesting take-away from the survey data so far was that a LOT of people claim to have read CONTRIBUTING.md
I admit that surprised me
but there is probably some space for us to put some material of that kind in there... or in somewhere linked to from there...
Yeah, that probably would be a good place for that especially as some of the more technical content seems to be moving to the rustc-guide.
Well, this has been very interesting to read!

From skimming the survey data, I think there are a handful of very clear action items (and a lot of things I don't know what to make of, but...). It seems like one very high priority thing is having a clear "getting started" guide (which we were already thinking about) that is aimed at beginners and says:

  • Here is where to ask questions
  • Here is who to ask questions
  • Here are the 5 most important command to build/test X (for various X)
  • Here is a list of other resources (like the rustc-dev-guide)

And the to link this "getting started" guide prominently on both rlo and the README in the repo.

nikomatsakis said:

BTW, one interesting take-away from the survey data so far was that a LOT of people claim to have read CONTRIBUTING.md

GitHub does steer people towards it any time they go to open an issue or PR.
Also, I've always found it interesting that our top-level README in rust-lang/rust is more aimed at people installing than people contributing.
That always seemed a bit backwards
People installing should be pointed to https://www.rust-lang.org/tools/install
what are people saying about CI?
@mark-i-m you think so? README.md is the main landing point for someone who finds rust on github... do you think the people who find it on github are interested in contributing? Or in using it?
(I would have assumed the latter)

Pietro Albini said:

what are people saying about CI?

11% (of almost 300 people) feel that CI times are too long. A handful of people have mentioned the order of bors queue as a bit odd. I think GHA will be a very pleasant improvement, but on the whole most people seemed to notice it (which is a testament to how well you and the infra/release teams have done, imho)
Also, in terms of problems that new contributors run into, I would say long CI times are less likely to be noticed by them...
I feel like the main README could probably just be very short

sort of

Welcome to Rust! It's an awesome language!

  • If you want to install Rust, go here.
  • If you want to contribute to Rust, check out the rustc-dev-guide.

pnkfelix said:

mark-i-m you think so? README.md is the main landing point for someone who finds rust on github... do you think the people who find it on github are interested in contributing? Or in using it?

Sorry, I somehow missed this comment

For a programming language, I assume that most people who go to the actual repo are interested in contributing or at least reading the code. If I want to use it, I tend to go the website. This is for programming languages specfically.

That is, if I ask myself, suppose I wanted to use Go or kotlin, what would I do? My immediate intuition is to go to golang.org or kotlin-lang.org (not sure if those exist, but that's what I would look for)

nikomatsakis said:

I feel like the main README could probably just be very short

Yes, Santiago mentioned something like that to me earlier, I'm starting to come around to this point of view
:+1:, yeah what Mark have said and agree with Niko :)
then rustc-dev-guide's could have a getting started first chapter that guides people through how to setup the environment and in general some basics about contributing
I guess something like that would make a lot of sense
btw, what do people mean by drive-by pings? sorry non native speaker so I don't get what that means exactly

nikomatsakis said:

pnkfelix said:

This ... is a super interesting point. I have to admit, I hadn't considered that we might be losing some elements of, well, "social community" with the move to Zulip

fwiw I had considered this and considered it a plus, but maybe it's not as much a clear plus as I thought... I do kind of think that "chattiness" can be also kind of frustrating and distracting at times, when you're trying to "get work done" :)

I was also talking in private with Felix about this, it's hard to find the right balance between the socializing part and getting work done meanwhile probably most of the people that are around are during their work hours

so yeah, as Felix has also said a dedicated stream may be the best solution considering both things, people could freely choose to be part of it or not and one could also have it muted so is not that distracting
although unsure what happens if you have a topic/stream muted and you're mentioned on it

Santiago Pastorino said:

although unsure what happens if you have a topic/stream muted and you're mentioned on it

You do get pinged in this case. I happen to have most zulip streams muted, but I occasionally get pinged in other places.

mark-i-m said:

For a programming language, I assume that most people who go to the actual repo are interested in contributing or at least reading the code. If I want to use it, I tend to go the website. This is for programming languages specfically.

I think I normally visit project github pages to have a feel of the activity, sometimes to see if there's important bugs, see if it's worth investing time learning it. I think that's the case for most people, where there's normally more users than contributors.
that said, it would be great to point people to the dev-guide

Santiago Pastorino said:

btw, what do people mean by drive-by pings? sorry non native speaker so I don't get what that means exactly

I don't remember the context, but if I said it, what I probably meant was like "people talking about a given topic and just pinging me without really asking me a question" -- e.g., "nikomatsakis said the problem was really hard..."
right, makes sense and I may have also done that too :), if so sorry
nah it's all good
I mean sometimes I am interested :)
anyway in general, it's good to know how others prefer to communicate
side note that Zulip allows you to tag people without notifying them
which is interesting
e.g., @_ (username)
yes, I use that a lot
that is, Santiago Pastorino won't get pinged for this :)
nikomatsakis says .. lol :)
you beated me
I think I might have too on other Rust projects :). What's the equivalent of the @_ (username for GitHub? Just without the @?
E.g., instead of @nikomatsakis, just nikomatsakis?
Yeah I guess so, I don't think there's an official syntax
I usually just right without the @ or I will put it in ticks so it is formatted as code, like you did just above
btw, https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/pull/731
